(Sarah of the Clue Crew presents from the Skansen Open-Air Museum in Stockholm, Sweden.) Skansen helps keep alive the culture of the Sami, or Lapp, people, who while finding grazing lands for their reindeer herds were historically known for roaming Norway, Sweden & Finland as this type of wandering society

(Sarah of the Clue Crew presents from the Skansen Open-Air Museum in Stockholm, Sweden.) Skansen preserved the summerhouse from the estate of the great 18th century mystic & author Emanuel Swedenborg, who lived there when he wrote "Secrets of Heaven", a verse-by-verse commentary on these first two books of the Old Testament

(Sarah of the Clue Crew presents from the Skansen Open-Air Museum in Stockholm, Sweden.) Among the 150 historic buildings preserved here at Skansen is the Seglora Church from 1729 & today, one of the region's most popular sites for these ceremonies, "bröllop" in Swedish

(Jimmy of the Clue Crew presents from the Skansen Open-Air Museum in Stockholm, Sweden.) Founded in 1891, Skansen Open-Air Museum was the first of a movement to preserve traditional architecture, like the farmhouse with this turf roof, widely used since the time of the Vikings

(Sarah of the Clue Crew presents from the Skansen Open-Air Museum in Stockholm, Sweden.) 18th century pharmacists, or apotekare in Swedish, were very hands-on, preparing drugs via distillation, or with mortar & pestle, or pressing herbs & adding them to alcohol to make these concentrated solutions
